item.title: Welcome to Crybot
item.description:
Welcome to Crybot!

Crybot is a modular personal AI assistant built in Crystal. I'm excited to share what I've been working on.

What is Crybot?

Crybot is your personal AI assistant that you can:

  • Chat with through a web interface, Telegram, voice, or command line
  • Extend with custom tools and skills
  • Automate with scheduled tasks
  • Connect to external services via MCP

Why Crystal?

I wanted to build something that was:

  • Fast - Crystal's performance is excellent
  • Type-safe - Catch errors at compile time
  • Concurrent - Fiber-based concurrency for scalability
  • Self-contained - Single binary deployment

Key Features

Multiple Interfaces

  • Web UI - Modern browser-based chat
  • REPL - Fancyline-powered command line
  • Telegram - Chat from your phone
  • Voice - Wake word activation

Skills System

Create reusable AI behaviors as simple markdown files. The agent can reference these skills to perform complex tasks consistently.

Scheduled Tasks

Automate recurring tasks like daily summaries, news digests, or any periodic AI work.

MCP Integration

Connect to the growing ecosystem of Model Context Protocol servers for browser automation, filesystem access, web search, and more.

Getting Started

git clone https://github.com/ralsina/crybot.git
cd crybot
shards install
shards build
./bin/crybot onboard
./bin/crybot start

What's Next?

This is just the beginning. I have plans for:

  • More channels (Discord, Matrix, email)
  • More built-in skills
  • Better voice interaction
  • Enhanced tool capabilities

Check out the GitHub repo and let me know what you think!

item.title: MCP Integration in Crybot
item.description:
MCP Integration in Crybot

I've just added Model Context Protocol (MCP) support to Crybot, opening up a world of possibilities for extending the AI assistant's capabilities.

What is MCP?

The Model Context Protocol is an open standard that allows AI applications to connect to external tools and data sources. Think of it as a universal plugin system for AI assistants.

How It Works in Crybot

Crybot acts as an MCP client, connecting to stdio-based MCP servers. When Crybot starts, it:

  1. Connects to all configured MCP servers
  2. Discovers what tools each server provides
  3. Registers those tools with the agent
  4. Makes tools available during conversations

Configuration

Add MCP servers to your ~/.crybot/config.yml:

mcp:
  servers:
    - name: playwright
      command: npx @playwright/mcp@latest

    - name: filesystem
      command: npx -y @modelcontextprotocol/server-filesystem /home/user/Documents

Using MCP Tools

Once configured, MCP tools are automatically available to the agent:

You: Navigate to example.com and take a screenshot
Crybot: [Uses playwright/browser_navigate]
       [Uses playwright/browser_take_screenshot]
       Done! Here's your screenshot...

Available MCP Servers

The MCP ecosystem is growing fast. Some popular servers:

  • @playwright/mcp - Browser automation
  • @modelcontextprotocol/server-filesystem - File operations
  • @modelcontextprotocol/server-brave-search - Web search
  • @modelcontextprotocol/server-github - GitHub integration
  • @modelcontextprotocol/server-postgres - Database queries

Find more at github.com/modelcontextprotocol/servers.

Web UI Management

Crybot's web UI includes an MCP Servers section where you can:

  • View configured servers
  • Add new servers
  • Remove servers
  • Reload configuration

Technical Details

The MCP implementation in Crybot:

  • Uses stdio transport for server communication
  • Supports fiber-based non-blocking I/O
  • Handles server failures gracefully
  • Prefixes tool names with server name
  • Integrates with Crybot's existing tool system

Future Plans

  • HTTP-based MCP servers
  • Bidirectional streaming
  • Resource support
  • Prompt templates

MCP integration makes Crybot incredibly extensible. What servers would you like to see supported?
